b'Through Sparks we\xe2\x80\x99ve donated over \xc2\xa37m to charities and in collaboration with our colleagues, we\xe2\x80\x99ve looked at our charity partners to make sure they reflect the issues that matter most to our colleagues, customers and communities. As a result, we\xe2\x80\x99ve partnered with 25 new Sparks charities and today we\xe2\x80\x99re shining a spotlight on our new Community & Inclusion causes.

We\xe2\x80\x99re doing this because as an employer, a retailer, and a brand, we need to take urgent action and accelerate our diversity and inclusion strategy.

As an employer of 78,000 colleagues with different backgrounds, beliefs and ambitions - we want to make sure we attract, support and develop diverse talent and create an inclusive culture where everyone feels they can belong and get on.

As a retailer, inclusivity should be embedded into how we do business \xe2\x80\x93 from the ranges we offer to the way we market them to the layout of our stores.

And in the communities our 1,000+ shops serve, we want to support organisations which work on community inclusion issues our colleagues and customers care about, using the power and platform of our brand to amplify their work.

Last week, we publicly acknowledged that respecting the silence of Blackout Tuesday was not good enough and that there is much more that needs to be done to truly understand and tackle systemic racism.

We\xe2\x80\x99ve worked with our colleague inclusion networks and listened to our customers to identify the organisations that matter most to them. It\xe2\x80\x99s a small step, but by supporting causes that tackle the inclusion issues our customers and colleagues care about, we hope we can make a positive difference.

That\xe2\x80\x99s why we\xe2\x80\x99re adding The Stephen Lawrence Charitable Trust (@S_Lawrencetrust), which was founded to tackle inequality in all forms and transform the life chances of young people, and The Black Curriculum (@theblackcurriculum), which aims to address the lack of Black British history in the UK Curriculum, to our Sparks charities.

And you can support them too. Every time you shop with Sparks, whether in-store or online, we\xe2\x80\x99ll donate to your chosen charity \xe2\x80\x93 so together, we can start to spark real change.

Find out more about Sparks on M&S.com.'

b'Earlier this week we respected the silence on Tuesday and paused activity across all of our social media channels. We talked to our colleagues about why we were doing this, but we didn\xe2\x80\x99t talk to our customers. We know we\xe2\x80\x99ve got work to do and so it didn\xe2\x80\x99t feel right to make a public statement; we know we need to start with ourselves. But we\xe2\x80\x99ve listened to what our colleagues and customers have told us, and we know that our silence might have looked like we didn\xe2\x80\x99t care. But we do care. And we know that if we are really going to be all in this together then we need to be vocal in standing up and standing for our black colleagues. So we\xe2\x80\x99re sharing with you what we shared with our colleagues.

The horrific death of George Floyd in Minneapolis last week has sparked a global protest against racism and injustice towards black people. The protest has been global because this is a global challenge, including in the UK, and it is right that we - as a UK business and an organisation of thousands of colleagues - show our support for everyone, everywhere who is impacted by racism, discrimination or bigotry.

As a 78,000 strong business - with colleagues working across the UK and the world - with different experiences and views, we must start with ourselves and make sure M&S is a place where everyone feels they can be their full selves and their voices are heard. Like most businesses and probably most people, we\xe2\x80\x99ve got work to do to make sure we are a truly inclusive place to be that encourages real diversity of thought and opinion. We committed to this change when we signed the Race at Work Charter which will help us frame some of the work we need to do internally.

Our colleague networks are also crucial in spearheading change, and we encourage all of our colleagues to take this moment to decide what individual action they can take and invite everyone - members of the black community and allies from all communities - to share what is on your mind. If we come together and join together we can make sure everyone\xe2\x80\x99s voice is heard and help combat injustice that impacts black people in all aspects of life.'
